content.description:
Climb through a series of difficult moves making use of crucial toe hooks leading to an explosive dyno to a sloper.  After latching the sloper, relax and soak it in as you finish up on good holds to the anchor.

This route climbs the tallest part of the unbroken face on the left side of Monster Wall. It shares an anchor with Shelob.
3 bolts

Climb the dike and face. Powerful gastons and lock-offs!

At the left end of Monster Wall. This route climbs the small corner/dike just right of a tree stump.
2 bolts. Quick Clips

Either chimney up the gully or climb up the small buttress of rock to the ledge. Lean over and clip the high first bolt. Climb up the arête to a fun roof pull. A few easy moves take you to the anchor in a corner. 
Pulling the roof is easier if you move a bit right.

Starts at the access gully between Monster Wall and Main Wall.
5 bolts. Quick Clips

climb the short wall past 2 bolts.

furthest route right on Monster Wall before getting to the Main Wall.
2 bolts, bolted anchor

Climb the overhanging dihedral through a series of powerful gastons before setting up for a heroes throw to a good jug in the horizontal break midway up the cliff.  From here the difficulty eases with interesting movement leading to the anchors.

This route climbs the overhanging dihedral just right of center on monster wall and directly left of Sharktopus.
5 bolts, quick clips

Start on the same holds as The Wolfman, but move slightly right into an undercling and bust straight up the face. Reach left or step left to clip the anchor. Fun moves, you'll be sad to see the anchor so quickly.

Just right of the left-leaning dihedral of The Wolfman
2 bolts. 1 cold shut

This is the extension to Quarantine. 
If you get to the anchors for Quarantine and still feel fresh, pull straight through the right side of the roof to a small face and a second, smaller roof. Skirt right around this second roof and onto easier terrain.

Climb Quarantine and continue through the roof.
9 bolts. quick-clip anchor. Bring a few long draws to keep the rope running nice. I suggest clipping an alpine draw in the Quarantine anchor

Climb through the first break to a good side-pull which leads to the crux dyno off a rippled sloping pinch to an edge below the second bolt.  Complete a few more tenuous moves to gain a jug over the lip and topout the ledge.  Celebrate and then continue up the overhanging face on good holds to the anchors.

This route climbs the face between Sharktopus and The Wolfman and continues straight up the overhanging face above the ledge.
5 bolts, quick clips

Fun sustained movement leads to a wild double-clutch throw to the 'Pumpkinhead'.

Located at the left end of Monster Wall. This route climbs the short overhanging face leading to anchors above an oblong shaped hold.
3 bolts, Quick clips

A combination of technique, finger strength and endurance will get you to the anchor just below the roof. Save some gas for the big span just before the anchor.

This route is located on the first wall you encounter after scrambling up the gully with the fixed rope.Look for the inviting face capped by a horizontal roof.
4 bolts, quick-clip anchor

Found on the left side of the main upper wall at Norton shore. Work up right into the corner, then up the steep corner past more bolts to bolt anchors below the roofs. We wanted to continue to the top but the rock wouldn’t stay on the wall. Fun pumpy line

Left on the main wall
5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Climb a small arête, using some good sidepulls on the right face. A tough move before turning the lip onto the small slab. Step a bit right on the slab and pull through the roof followed by moderate climbing to the top.

note: this route used to end when you reach the small slab but was extended to the top by F.Côté in 2020.

near what one could call the middle of Monster Wall, where there is a break/gully leading downhill (not the typical approach gully).
5 bolts. quick clip anchor

Climb easy terrain to the roof feature. Skirt around the right edge of the roof (kneebar), and follow the left angling crack on mostly good holds to a bolted anchor.
Despite the good holds, it's still pretty steep, so the quicker you place gear, the less pumped you will get.

On the left side of Monster Wall, there is a roof feature which starts low and angles up and right. Where this feature ends, there is a crack which angles up and left. Shelob climbs this crack.
a handful of cams up to 2"

Climb up the first two bolts of Screech Bombers, but instead of traversing all the way into the corner, climb up the beautiful gently overhanging face. Continue past a small arête then pull the bulge and trend right on jugs to the anchor.
A wonderful combination of technical and pumpy climbing.

The face just left of the obvious bolted corner of Screech Bombers
8 bolts, quick clip anchor

Fun, sustained movement on relatively decent holds.

Climb up a series of small right-facing features to gain the hanging dihedral. Navigate this to the horn at its top, then a couple easier moves to the anchor.

This route unfortunately seeps a bit more than most routes on the wall but when it's dry, this route is not to be missed!



Just left of the tallest part of Monster Wall. Look for an obvious right-facing dihedral part way up the cliff.

5 bolts, cold shuts.

Although very short, this one packs a punch! Move up into a horizontal and surmount the small left-leaning dihedral/roof. Move right after the second bolt to jugs above the anchor.

look for the small steep left-leaning, left facing dihedral.
2 bolts, 1 cold shut

Monster Wall and Main wall are part of the same cliff band so I included them as one area. An access gully separates the two sections of the cliff.
Monster Wall is the place to crank some short burly routes. Peter Adamson established a few climbs in 2012 but the cliff sat idle for many years until the spring of 2020 when a small band of climbers decided to revive the area and add to the existing selection of routes. There is very little overhanging rock in N.B. which makes this crag a rare little gem for those who want to pull hard moves. Most routes are very bouldery and the rock is deceptively steep. 
Main Wall is significantly taller. The left side of Main wall is characterized by a couple nice face climbs (gently overhanging) and blocky roofs. The right side is vertical or a bit slabby and very dirty. A few routes have been led on gear or toproped but this part of the cliff has not yet seen much development.

As with any of the areas in Hampton Marsh, the rock quality is not always the best and helmets are recommended.
